reporting-org.narrative: Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Helping children worldwide - Foundation

title.narrative: Emergency COVID-19 pandemic adapted WASH, Protection, and Basic Needs Assistance for vulnerable returnee and/or IDP communities in post-conflict Iraq

description.narrative: A large share of the funds initially allocated to the 'Improving Prospects for Refugees and Host Communities in Iraq' project (20119723a) was reprogrammed to this Covid-19 response.
Tdh targets communities in a location not specified here, in particular rural and remote areas that are most vulnerable and at risk of Covid-19.

Terre des hommes (Tdh) implements a 7-month long integrated child protection, WASH, and basic needs response to firstly reduce children’s vulnerability to increased protection risks; secondly to support the mitigation and control of the COVID-19 pandemic among already vulnerable returnee and IDP households; and thirdly to ensure life-sustaining assistance for households and children facing steep vulnerability due to the collateral impact of the health crisis in Iraq.

participating-org.narrative: Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Helping children worldwide - Foundation
Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Helping children worldwide - Foundation

organisation.narrative: Terre des hommes Foundation

receiver-org.narrative: Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation

title.narrative: Children and adolescents with increased protection concerns due to Covid-19 are identified and are directly supported and have access to required services (Output 1.1)
Indicator 1.1.4 - Number of children benefiting from Learning/PSS kits
Indicator 1.1.3 - Number of child protection cases referred to other organisations and successfully supported
Indicator 1.1.1 - Number of children and adolescents with urgent protection concerns directly supported by Tdh Case workers

Indicator 1.1.2 - Number of children and adolescents with protection concerns amongst recently returned IDPs directly benefitting from individual psychosocial and mental health support and Legal Support (f/m)
Households vulnerable to COVID-19 have access to gender-responsive COVID-19 prevention kits and COVID-19 cleaning kits (Output 2.2).
Indicator 2.2.2 - Number of households that receive COVID-19 cleaning kits
Indicator 2.2.1 - Number of individuals most vulnerable to COVID-19 who receive essential gender-responsive COVID-19 prevention kits
Community-based structures and services to identify and support vulnerable families are strenghtened (Output 1.2).
Indicator 1.2.2 - Percentage of CPC members/FPs who demonstrate an improved knowledge, attitude and practices on child protection principles and identification of vulnerable families
Indicator 1.2.1 - Number of child protection committee members /FPs supported and trained (m/f)
Households vulnerable to COVID-19 have access to awareness on prevention, health and hygiene practices related to COVID-19 (Output 2.1).
Indicator 2.1.3 - Number of children that benefit from age-tailored health and hygiene recreational kits
Indicator 2.1.1 - Number of individuals that receive COVID-19 IEC materials
Indicator 2.1.2 - Number of individuals in households vulnerable to COVID-19 that receive one-on-one prevention, health, and hygiene awareness sessions.
Households facing collateral basic needs and/or protection impact due to COVID-19 receive inclusive tailored assistance (Output 3.1).
Indicator 3.1.2 - Number of beneficiaries that are identified to be in need of additional support that receive internal and/or external referrals
Indicator 3.1.1- Number of returnees and/or IDPs particularly vulnerable to the pandemic that receive tailored multi-purpose assistance

reporting-org.narrative: Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Helping children worldwide - Foundation

title.narrative: Improving Prospects for Refugees and Host Communities in Iraq

description.narrative: Due to Covid-19, a large share of funds from this project were re-programmed to a Covid-19 follow-on project: Emergency Covid-19 Pandemic adapted Wash, Protection, and Basic Needs Assistance for vulnerable returnee and/or IDP communities in Iraq (20119723b).

In the areas most affected by the conflict in Iraq, the humanitarian needs are dire as displaced populations return home. With major damage to basic infrastructure, scarce employment opportunities and limited public services, it is vital to create the conditions for a durable and dignified return. Recent returnee households experience a general impoverishment that conducts them to resort to negative and risky coping strategies and mechanisms. Children and adolescents are particularly vulnerable to protection risks, with assessments showing increasing rates of child labour, child marriage and violence directed at children amongst the returnee population. In light of these needs and risks, Tdh implements a programme to strengthen the protection, resilience and prospects of vulnerable children and adolescents among recently returned IDPs.

participating-org.narrative: Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Helping children worldwide - Foundation
Terre des hommes - Aide à l'enfance dans le monde - Fondation
Terre des hommes - Helping children worldwide - Foundation

activity-date.narrative: The planned end date for this project was 30 April 2021

organisation.narrative: Terre des hommes Foundation

title.narrative: "Access to vital information regarding COVID19 pandemic" - Projet COVID-19 - H2H

description.narrative: The fears expressed by the World Health Organisation of an “infodemic” – false information that spreads like an epidemic – accompanying the Covid-19 pandemic are coming true. Certain populations have been stigmatised and targeted, ineffective and dangerous remedies are being promoted, distrust in authorities and in preventive measures is mounting. Access to quality, reliable information is a basic necessity in this context. By providing reliable information, in real time and accessible to the greatest number of people, professional and trusted media facilitate the response of humanitarian actors and health professionals for the prevention of the pandemic, the provision of care, protection measures and the reconstruction of social links. Through fact-checking journalistic work, they help defuse rumours, combat misinformation and myths circulating among the population, and relay calls for calm. They provide information on gestures and attitudes, on the development of the general situation, access to care and the possibilities of movement. The media can also contribute to the reorganization of daily life, the provision of public services. They alert local authorities and accompany their initiatives and those of the international actors. They help to rebuild social ties, create dialogue in response to the risks of conflict generated by the pandemic, and play a role of "companion" in the face of feelings of isolation, and foster solidarity and trust. To respond to the situation described above, the Fondation Hirondelle launched a Global CVID-19 Project. This funding will allow us to add Guinea, Sierra Leone, and Uganda to this global program. This program is already underway and informing up to 65 million people through our Fondation Hirondelle-run media projects in Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, RCA, DRC, Madagascar, and Myanmar. We are in negotiation with trusted partners in South Sudan and Cameroun to begin informing populations in those countries as well. A dedicated COVID19 editorial and operational team is actively supporting all of these operations. The following activities will be implemented : Production of vital information on the pandemic for a broad audience includes (1) daily or bi-weekly information relevant for in each country; (2) identify rumours and respond with confirmed facts, especially in digital media. This will include prevention messaging; (3) Local languages will be chosen for key messaging to reach the largest number of people, as well as specific vulnerable groups (such as refugees in Uganda). Distribution of information will be on existing networks including FM radio, social media, and possibly push SMS services, WhatsApp, and call-in telephone messages (VIAMO in Uganda). An 8- month programme from May to December is justified, with more capacity focused on the first critical 6 months, and 3 months focusing on recovery and stabilisation, and including research partners to better understand the role of communication and journalism during a pandemic. Observations will be shared for example in CERAH classrooms and with other partners including CDAC, TWB, The New Humanitarian etc.

participating-org.narrative: Association des Journalistes Scientifiques de Guinée

organisation.narrative: Fondation Hirondelle
Fondation Hirondelle

policy-marker.narrative: Immediate Objective 1 : Contribute to the global response and reduce the risk of instability linked to Covid-19 by facilitating access to reliable, credible and targeted information for the populations of 3 countries.
Immediate Objective 2 : Support local media in their social and vital role of informing the populations in times of crisis
